description: Not sure if it's a flathub or an issue of this package, but it looks as if this package does not support Jack what is more or less a showstopper for any serious DAW work on Linux.

Not functioning... I haven't tried the analog onbaord audio on awhile, but last time I tried it; nothing could come through except static.  Also I have a firewire card and use jack for an external a/d converter via firewire that has 1/4 " inputs and I can monitor with it. It doesn't list jack as an audio source here on Clear Linux. I have used Ardour before with this equipment and it works. Like on Ubuntu using Ubuntu repository's, but not this here on Clear Linux. It doesn't pick up jack2, which has me confused because it says installed; but I do not remember configuring it.

Where to start. Oh yes... I compiled the source on ubuntu (sandboxed in virtual box, I'm on EL8) It gives a real PAIN with Jack and when you end figuring that you need to add yourself to the audio users group can still fail anyway. Driven by curiosity, I paid a few bucks for their "ready to use binary" be aware, it's not actually more than the same that I got compiling it with a the same script to move it to the /opt folder. This kind of witchcraft with open source software to force donations deserves that the software fall into darkness. Sure, is awesome if you use a distro like Ubuntu studio or Fedora Jam. But DONT use this on a regular workstation. And forget about this flatpak, this will not even pick up an USB microphone. So, You want to make music? Grab a distro like the mentioned above and install them on a USB stick problem solved.
If audacity gets a makeup update, I'll stick to it. because it works like a charm. oh yes... Unless you want to install a lot of BS you are going to have a bad time getting plugins to actually look and work fairly fine.
This is already Windows software, and with forced donations and a subscription model. Cheers.
not working, i hate this app

Unable to install Ardour:
fedora: manifest hash in downloaded content does not match ref app/
org.ardour.Ardour/x86_64/stable...

cant install Fedora-Flatpak Ardour on my system couse some hash does not match...

Ardour is a great DAW to use for musicians or anyone working in sound design, audio engineering, podcasting, film, music, all-around basic audio editing sessions, etc. Even as a Pro Tools / Logic Pro user for years, Ardour is a great alternative and it was pretty easy to learn to use. If need be, use their website manual and forum page to find the features you are looking for. Most of your basic editing features are easy to find. It's now my main DAW and it has many great, professional features to enjoy. Although it was made natively on to run Linux, you will enjoy that the developers also make it available for download on macOS and Windows through their website too. I especially enjoy that this software is licensed in GPLv2 which allows me to install Ardour on all of my computers with ease. I highly recommend Ardour!
summary: Great DAW For Musicians, Audio Engineers, and Beyond

description: I really want to like this app. It's really cool looking, It has lots of good features, and it's open source... but It's missing some essential/key features to be useful. I look forward to see what this evolves into.
